content.description:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Scientists studied soybean plants grown in sunlit, controlled-environment chambers with a carbon dioxide <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> concentration of <math alttext="700 micromoles of C O 2 per mol" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>700</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>μmol</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>/</mo><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></math> of air. The <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentration in the chambers was approximately double that of normal concentrations of environmental <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>.

Photosynthetic rate is measured by the amount of <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> exchanged in an area of leaf surface over time. The rate is directly influenced by the activity of the plant enzyme rubisco. During photosynthesis, rubisco fixes atmospheric carbon into an organic molecule as one of the first steps in the Calvin cycle.

Scientists measured the amount of carbon fixation that occurred in the leaves of soybean plants grown at each temperature shown in Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Carbon Fixation by Rubisco Under Different Temperatures

Temperature (<math alttext="degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)
 Carbon Fixation <math alttext="plus or minus 2 standard errors of the mean, in micromoles per square meter per second" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>μmol</mtext><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

<math alttext="25" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="91 plus or minus 9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>91</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="96 plus or minus 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>96</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="93 plus or minus 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="104 plus or minus 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>104</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="45" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="71 plus or minus 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>71</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="59 plus or minus 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>59</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: (a) Describe the effect on an enzyme of an increase in environmental temperature above the optimum temperature range of the enzyme.

frqParts.text: (a) Describe the effect on an enzyme of an increase in environmental temperature above the optimum temperature range of the enzyme.

(b) Using the template in the space provided for your response, construct an appropriately labeled graph to represent the data in Table <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Determine whether there is a statistical difference in the amount of <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> fixed by rubisco at <math alttext="30 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="40 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(c) Based on the data, identify the temperature range at which the soybean leaves are producing the lowest amount of carbohydrate.

(d) Increased amounts of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere are correlated with increased global surface temperatures. Based on the data, predict how a surface temperature that continues to rise above <math alttext="40 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> most likely affects the amount of energy available to primary consumers in an ecosystem. Provide reasoning to justify your prediction. One model predicts that an increase in greenhouse gases will lead to a <math alttext="2 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increase in average surface temperature on Earth. Based on the data from the experiment and the prediction of an increase in average surface temperature by the model, predict how the locations of plant species are expected to change over time.
